activity-description.narrative: Clean-up and rehabilitation of regulated riverbeds and drainage networks in the Strumica River Basin
Clean-up and rehabilitation of regulated riverbeds and drainage networks in the Strumica River Basin
Clean-up and rehabilitation of regulated riverbeds and drainage networks in the Strumica River Basin

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Output 1: • Total length of cleaned/restored river regulations and drainage network (improved discharge capacity): a. Crna Reka: 57 km of main regulated riverbed 106 km secondary channel network and drainage canals (tributaries) 600 m restored embankments on Crna Reka b. Strumica: 24 km of main regulated riverbed • Minimum original (design) flood conveyance capacity is achieved in restored river sections/drainage canals • Minimum four reconstructed dams / reservoirs (Mavrovica, Drenska Reka, Lipa and Slatina dams) • Reduced frequency in overflowing of recovered dams (as a result of improved operating regimes)
Output 2: • Optimization models for minimum four (4) dams/reservoirs • Guidance document for incorporating the ‘build back better’ principle in the reconstruction of water infrastructure projects • # of knowledge products and public awareness material

comment.narrative:
Output 1 26 percent of the drainage systems, 17 percent of the irrigation systems and 3 percent of the dams were damaged in 32 municipalities. The dams of Mavrovica, Slatina, Drenska and Lipa suffered major damage during the early 2015 floods. As a result their flood control and other purposes are undermined The drainage network and regulated riverbeds in the Crna Reka and Strumica River Basins are damaged and poorly maintained. As a result they perform their flood mitigation function only in a very limited fashion.
Output 2 The operating regimes of existing flood control structures (dams/reservoirs) do not maximize their flood mitigation potential. There is limited understanding of the ‘building back better’ approach and enhanced resilience objectives in reconstruction projects at national level.

1. River channel clean-up and rehabilitation works are completed in the Pelagonija region resulting in reduction of potential flood-related damages and losses of app. 35% 2. Recovery efforts are completed on two remaining selected priority dams 3. Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented through a second comprehensive survey/opinion poll 4. Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the water/flood control infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

1. Recovery/clean-up works in Pelagonija – a flood-sensitive region with the highest investment needs – have been entirely completed. Following the clean-up of vegetation from 43.4 km of flood control canals, the project supported the clean-up of sediment deposits from an additional 23 km of canal network. Works also included reconstruction of damaged earth embankments on priority sections, prioritized by applying a risk-based approach. Thanks to these interventions over 230,000 people living in the six municipalities of the region are already benefiting from the avoided average annual damage of over 2,000,000 USD from future flood events with return period of 50 years. These benefits are the result of the protection of approximately 5,500 hectares of agricultural land, 35 hectares of urbanized area and industrial zone, and 10 hectares of transport infrastructure.
2. The recovery works on all four pre-selected dams (Mavrovica, Lipa, Slatino and Drenska Reka) have been completed in line with the “build back better” approach. Moreover, budgetary savings were used to support rehabilitation activities on a fifth dam (Prilep in the Pelagonija region). All five recovered dams provide improved flood control functions, as well as more efficient supply of water for irrigation and other purposes.
3. Analysis of changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and recovery needs, and the role of the UNDP work were conducted during the final stages of the project. A final opinion poll captured important changes in flood awareness and knowledge and link them to the achievements of the work of UNDP. The survey revealed an increase in people’s knowledge about programme’s importance and results compared to the situation at the time of the first survey in 2016.
4. Overcoming the multiple and multilayer complex challenges to achieving the desired results (e.g., legal and institutional, quality of designs, contractor performance) has generated valuable experiences and lessons that have been summarized in the guidance document/manual for integrating the ‘build back better’ concept into engineering designs. The document has been prepared and communicated with the key stakeholders.

1. River channel clean-up and rehabilitation works are completed in the Pelagonija region resulting in reduction of potential flood-related damages and losses of app. 35% 2. Recovery efforts are completed on two remaining selected priority dams 3. Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented through a second comprehensive survey/opinion poll 4. Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the water/flood control infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

1. Recovery/clean-up works in Pelagonija – a flood-sensitive region with the highest investment needs – have been entirely completed. Following the clean-up of vegetation from 43.4 km of flood control canals, the project supported the clean-up of sediment deposits from an additional 23 km of canal network. Works also included reconstruction of damaged earth embankments on priority sections, prioritized by applying a risk-based approach. Thanks to these interventions over 230,000 people living in the six municipalities of the region are already benefiting from the avoided average annual damage of over 2,000,000 USD from future flood events with return period of 50 years. These benefits are the result of the protection of approximately 5,500 hectares of agricultural land, 35 hectares of urbanized area and industrial zone, and 10 hectares of transport infrastructure.
2. The recovery works on all four pre-selected dams (Mavrovica, Lipa, Slatino and Drenska Reka) have been completed in line with the “build back better” approach. Moreover, budgetary savings were used to support rehabilitation activities on a fifth dam (Prilep in the Pelagonija region). All five recovered dams provide improved flood control functions, as well as more efficient supply of water for irrigation and other purposes.
3. Analysis of changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and recovery needs, and the role of the UNDP work were conducted during the final stages of the project. A final opinion poll captured important changes in flood awareness and knowledge and link them to the achievements of the work of UNDP. The survey revealed an increase in people’s knowledge about programme’s importance and results compared to the situation at the time of the first survey in 2016.
4. Overcoming the multiple and multilayer complex challenges to achieving the desired results (e.g., legal and institutional, quality of designs, contractor performance) has generated valuable experiences and lessons that have been summarized in the guidance document/manual for integrating the ‘build back better’ concept into engineering designs. The document has been prepared and communicated with the key stakeholders.

1. Average annual damages from medium probability floods in the Strumica River Basin are reduced by 10% compared to their current baseline levels. 2. Average annual damages from medium probability floods in the Pelagonija region are reduced by 35% compared to their current baseline levels. 3. Recovery efforts are initiated in two out of four selected priority dams in flood-sensitive regions in the country 4. A baseline on the current levels of community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs is established through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll.

1. The clean-up of almost 30 km of river canals network in the Strumica River Basin – one of country’s most flood-sensitive regions – improves the resilience of the region against future flood events. The discharge capacity of canals has been increased by ~50% that would prevent average annual damage of nearly 50,000-100,000 USD caused by future flood events with high probability of occurrence. To achieve higher protection, recovery of damaged parts of flood protection embankments still remains to be performed. 2. Almost 45 km of damaged and largely neglected river canals/flood control network in the Pelagonija region has been cleaned-up and rehabilitated to improve protection of agricultural and urbanized land. Over 230,000 people living in the six municipalities of the region will directly benefit from the avoided average annual damage of over 2,000,000 USD from future flood events with return period of 50 years, as a result of the improved discharge capacity of the rehabilitated priority river sections. These benefits are result from the protection of ~5.500 hectares of agricultural land, 35 hectares of urbanized area and industrial zone, and 10 hectares of transport infrastructure. 3. The recovery of two out of four selected dams damaged by the floods in 2015 has been initiated in line with the ‘build back better’ principles. Once completed the rehabilitation works will improve operation of Mavrovica and Lipa dams in satisfying various uses (e.g., irrigation and flood control) in two municipalities severely affected by the 2015-floods with total population of nearly 40,000 people (Mavrovica dam in Sveti Nikole and Lipa dam in Negotino). 4. Through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs has been established. These findings informed the design and implementation of the ongoing awareness raising programme targeting key communities and beneficiaries. Similar survey at the end of the programme will measure the effectiveness of the communication and awareness raising work in the selected priority flood-sensitive regions.

1. Average annual damages from medium probability floods in the Strumica River Basin are reduced by 10% compared to their current baseline levels. 2. Average annual damages from medium probability floods in the Pelagonija region are reduced by 35% compared to their current baseline levels. 3. Recovery efforts are initiated in two out of four selected priority dams in flood-sensitive regions in the country 4. A baseline on the current levels of community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs is established through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll.

1. The clean-up of almost 30 km of river canals network in the Strumica River Basin – one of country’s most flood-sensitive regions – improves the resilience of the region against future flood events. The discharge capacity of canals has been increased by ~50% that would prevent average annual damage of nearly 50,000-100,000 USD caused by future flood events with high probability of occurrence. To achieve higher protection, recovery of damaged parts of flood protection embankments still remains to be performed. 2. Almost 45 km of damaged and largely neglected river canals/flood control network in the Pelagonija region has been cleaned-up and rehabilitated to improve protection of agricultural and urbanized land. Over 230,000 people living in the six municipalities of the region will directly benefit from the avoided average annual damage of over 2,000,000 USD from future flood events with return period of 50 years, as a result of the improved discharge capacity of the rehabilitated priority river sections. These benefits are result from the protection of ~5.500 hectares of agricultural land, 35 hectares of urbanized area and industrial zone, and 10 hectares of transport infrastructure. 3. The recovery of two out of four selected dams damaged by the floods in 2015 has been initiated in line with the ‘build back better’ principles. Once completed the rehabilitation works will improve operation of Mavrovica and Lipa dams in satisfying various uses (e.g., irrigation and flood control) in two municipalities severely affected by the 2015-floods with total population of nearly 40,000 people (Mavrovica dam in Sveti Nikole and Lipa dam in Negotino). 4. Through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs has been established. These findings informed the design and implementation of the ongoing awareness raising programme targeting key communities and beneficiaries. Similar survey at the end of the programme will measure the effectiveness of the communication and awareness raising work in the selected priority flood-sensitive regions.

• River channel clean-up and rehabilitation works are completed in both Strumica River Basin and Pelagonija region resulting in reduction of potential flood-related damages and losses of 10% and 35% respectively • Recovery efforts are initiated on all four selected priority dams and two of them are fully recovered • Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented through a second comprehensive survey/opinion poll • Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the water/flood control infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

• The recovery/clean-up of flood control canal network in the Strumica River Basin – one of country’s most flood-sensitive regions – has been successfully completed. The discharge capacity of over 30 km of canals has been increased by ~50%, securing effective flood prevention of average annual damage of nearly 50,000-100,000 USD, caused by future flood events with high probability of occurrence. The recovered infrastructure already proved to be functional during the most recent flood events.
• The large proportion of recovery/clean-up works in the Pelagonija region have been completed. Following the clean-up of almost 45 km of flood control canals from vegetation, the project completed additional 23 km of clean-up of sediments. Works also included reconstruction of damaged earth embankments on priority sections. Project plans foreseen continuation of clean-up/recovery work on additional length of approximately 30 km that is planned to be completed in 2018 (subject to funds availability). Upon finalization of all activities in the Pelagonija region, over 230,000 people living in the six municipalities of the region will directly benefit from the avoided average annual damage of over 2,000,000 USD from future flood events with return period of 50 years. These benefits are result from the protection of ~5.500 hectares of agricultural land, 35 hectares of urbanized area and industrial zone, and 10 hectares of transport infrastructure.
• Following a complex preparatory processes, the project initiated the recovery works on all four pre-selected dams. Two of the dams are already reconstructed in line with the ‘build back better’ concept (Mavrovica and Lipa) and works are progressing well on the other two dams (Slatino and Drenska Reka).
• The final survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs is planned for the final stages of project implementation. The survey will attempt to measure the effectiveness of the communication and awareness raising work in the selected priority flood-sensitive regions.
• Overcoming complex challenges affecting project implementation (e.g., legal and institutional, quality of designs, contractor performance) has generated for the project valuable experiences and lessons that were summarized in a guidance document/manual for integrating the ‘build back better’ concept into engineering designs. The document has been completed and communicated with the key stakeholders. It’s publishing is planned for early 2018 following the completion of the consultations.

• River channel clean-up and rehabilitation works are completed in both Strumica River Basin and Pelagonija region resulting in reduction of potential flood-related damages and losses of 10% and 35% respectively • Recovery efforts are initiated on all four selected priority dams and two of them are fully recovered • Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented through a second comprehensive survey/opinion poll • Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the water/flood control infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

• The recovery/clean-up of flood control canal network in the Strumica River Basin – one of country’s most flood-sensitive regions – has been successfully completed. The discharge capacity of over 30 km of canals has been increased by ~50%, securing effective flood prevention of average annual damage of nearly 50,000-100,000 USD, caused by future flood events with high probability of occurrence. The recovered infrastructure already proved to be functional during the most recent flood events.
• The large proportion of recovery/clean-up works in the Pelagonija region have been completed. Following the clean-up of almost 45 km of flood control canals from vegetation, the project completed additional 23 km of clean-up of sediments. Works also included reconstruction of damaged earth embankments on priority sections. Project plans foreseen continuation of clean-up/recovery work on additional length of approximately 30 km that is planned to be completed in 2018 (subject to funds availability). Upon finalization of all activities in the Pelagonija region, over 230,000 people living in the six municipalities of the region will directly benefit from the avoided average annual damage of over 2,000,000 USD from future flood events with return period of 50 years. These benefits are result from the protection of ~5.500 hectares of agricultural land, 35 hectares of urbanized area and industrial zone, and 10 hectares of transport infrastructure.
• Following a complex preparatory processes, the project initiated the recovery works on all four pre-selected dams. Two of the dams are already reconstructed in line with the ‘build back better’ concept (Mavrovica and Lipa) and works are progressing well on the other two dams (Slatino and Drenska Reka).
• The final survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs is planned for the final stages of project implementation. The survey will attempt to measure the effectiveness of the communication and awareness raising work in the selected priority flood-sensitive regions.
• Overcoming complex challenges affecting project implementation (e.g., legal and institutional, quality of designs, contractor performance) has generated for the project valuable experiences and lessons that were summarized in a guidance document/manual for integrating the ‘build back better’ concept into engineering designs. The document has been completed and communicated with the key stakeholders. It’s publishing is planned for early 2018 following the completion of the consultations.
